thread.title: Bluejays keep Cloverwood title hopes alive
thread.title_full: Bluejays keep Cloverwood title hopes alive

title: Bluejays keep Cloverwood title hopes alive
persons: Tim Johnson/Daily Herald Media Tim Johnson
text:
Activate your digital access. Bluejays keep Cloverwood title hopes alive The Bluejays and Blackhawks came together in a key Week 8 matchup and also showed support for Owen-Withee's Will Maki and his battle with cancer. Tim Johnson/Daily Herald Media Tim Johnson , Daily Herald Media 7:38 a.m. CDT October 10, 2015 Buy Photo Owen-Withee's Kevin Kitlica(2), right, attempts to shake off Athens' Klay Ellenbecker(43) during Friday night's Cloverwood Conference boys football matchup at Athens High School football field. (Photo: T'xer Zhon Kha/Daily Herald Media) Buy Photo 44 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
ATHENS — The last thing the Bluejays were focused on after a convincing loss to Assumption last month was a conference title. 
“Right after (the loss), the coaches were just telling us that we needed to get better,” Athens junior running back Jake Stange said. “It was about just getting better every week.” 
The Bluejays have responded with four straight wins since the loss, including a 28-19 victory at home against Owen-Withee on Friday. 
The win over the Blackhawks gives Athens the opportunity to earn a share of the Cloverwood Conference championship with Abbotsford with a win over the Falcons next week to close out the regular season. The Bluejays have had at least a share of the last four conference titles. 
Stange rushed for 200 yards and three long touchdowns as the Bluejays improved to 7-1 overall and in the Cloverwood, a game behind Abbotsford. 
Two of his scores, 54- and 70-yard runs, came on consecutive carries in the first half. 
The junior’s 42-yard score gave Athens a 28-7 lead in the third quarter. 
“All week we felt we could get a dive (play) on them, but I didn’t know we would get that big of a play,” Athens coach Mike Thurs said. “We didn’t expect to get big runs tonight. We thought we would maybe get five or six yards a carry. (Stange) is explosive and quick. When he gets in the open field, I don’t think there are a lot of people who can catch him.” Buy Photo 
Owen-Withee's quarterback Josiah Goerlitz(13) runs the ball while Athens' Max Stange(26) tackles during Friday night's Cloverwood Conference boys football matchup at Athens High School football field. (Photo: T'xer Zhon Kha/Daily Herald Media) 
Kole Karaba scored on runs of eight and four yards in the fourth quarter for the Blackhawks. Owen-Withee was hampered by three turnovers in the game and 14 penalties, including one in the second quarter that wiped out a 48-yard touchdown run by quarterback Josiah Goerlitz. 
Kevin Kitlica rushed for 120 yards to lead the Falcons, and Karaba added 76 yards on the ground. 
“Our defense did a nice job tonight, holding a good team like that to 19 points,” Thurs said. “We are pretty happy with that.” 
The game wasn’t the only thing on the teams’ minds. 
The Bluejays sported yellow socks for the game in support of Owen-Withee’s Will Maki.
